DOC.brief_summary: The MATCH study ( Mexican-American Trial Community Health Workers ) test hypothesis use indigenous Community Health Workers ( CHWs ) , recruit target community train provide culturally appropriate diabetes education , promote pro-active self-management among inner-city dwell Mexican-Americans Type 2 diabetes mellitus . The study aim demonstrate CHW , compare attention control , : 1 ) result improvement short term physiologic outcome ( Hemoglobin A1c level blood pressure ) , 2 ) result increase frequency self-management behavior ( daily self blood-glucose monitoring , medication adherence , adherence diet physical activity recommendation ) . The study design single site , partially blind , randomize control trial 144 patient Type 2 diabetes mellitus . Eligibility criterion include diagnosis Type 2 diabetes , residence target community area Chicago area , Mexican Mexican-American ethnic heritage . Participants randomize either experimental group receive 36 home visit two year period CHW deliver diabetes education self-management skill training , attention control consist 36 bilingual diabetes education newsletter cover curriculum CHWs . The curriculum cover recommend diabetes self-management behavior include glucose self-monitoring , respond abnormal blood glucose level , work effectively health care provider , medication adherence , foot care , daily physical activity , reduce fat content diet . CHWs also deliver train behavioral skill self-monitoring , environmental restructuring , engagement social support , stress management , problem-solving skill facilitate self-management activity .
